2945 def line(self, x=None, y=None, **kwds): 

2946 """ 

2947 Plot DataFrame columns as lines. 

2948 

2949 This function is useful to plot lines using DataFrame's values 

2950 as coordinates. 

2951 

2952 Parameters 

2953 ---------- 

2954 x : int or str, optional 

2955 Columns to use for the horizontal axis. 

2956 Either the location or the label of the columns to be used. 

2957 By default, it will use the DataFrame indices. 

2958 y : int, str, or list of them, optional 

2959 The values to be plotted. 

2960 Either the location or the label of the columns to be used. 

2961 By default, it will use the remaining DataFrame numeric columns. 

2962 **kwds 

2963 Keyword arguments to pass on to :meth:`pandas.DataFrame.plot`. 

2964 

2965 Returns 

2966 ------- 

2967 axes : :class:`matplotlib.axes.Axes` or :class:`numpy.ndarray` 

2968 Returns an ndarray when ``subplots=True``. 

2969 

2970 See Also 

2971 -------- 

2972 matplotlib.pyplot.plot : Plot y versus x as lines and/or markers. 

2973 

2974 Examples 

2975 -------- 

2976 

2977 .. plot:: 

2978 :context: close-figs 

2979 

2980 The following example shows the populations for some animals 

2981 over the years. 

2982 

2983 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({ 

2984 ... 'pig': [20, 18, 489, 675, 1776], 

2985 ... 'horse': [4, 25, 281, 600, 1900] 

2986 ... }, index=[1990, 1997, 2003, 2009, 2014]) 

2987 >>> lines = df.plot.line() 

2988 

2989 .. plot:: 

2990 :context: close-figs 

2991 

2992 An example with subplots, so an array of axes is returned. 

2993 

2994 >>> axes = df.plot.line(subplots=True) 

2995 >>> type(axes) 

2996 <class 'numpy.ndarray'> 

2997 

2998 .. plot:: 

2999 :context: close-figs 

3000 

3001 The following example shows the relationship between both 

3002 populations. 

3003 

3004 >>> lines = df.plot.line(x='pig', y='horse') 

3005 """ 

3006 return self(kind='line', x=x, y=y, **kwds) 

3007 

3008 def bar(self, x=None, y=None, **kwds): 

3009 """ 

3010 Vertical bar plot. 

3011 

3012 A bar plot is a plot that presents categorical data with 

3013 rectangular bars with lengths proportional to the values that they 

3014 represent. A bar plot shows comparisons among discrete categories. One 

3015 axis of the plot shows the specific categories being compared, and the 

3016 other axis represents a measured value. 

3017 

3018 Parameters 

3019 ---------- 

3020 x : label or position, optional 

3021 Allows plotting of one column versus another. If not specified, 

3022 the index of the DataFrame is used. 

3023 y : label or position, optional 

3024 Allows plotting of one column versus another. If not specified, 

3025 all numerical columns are used. 

3026 **kwds 

3027 Additional keyword arguments are documented in 

3028 :meth:`pandas.DataFrame.plot`. 

3029 

3030 Returns 

3031 ------- 

3032 axes : matplotlib.axes.Axes or np.ndarray of them 

3033 An ndarray is returned with one :class:`matplotlib.axes.Axes` 

3034 per column when ``subplots=True``. 

3035 

3036 See Also 

3037 -------- 

3038 pandas.DataFrame.plot.barh : Horizontal bar plot. 

3039 pandas.DataFrame.plot : Make plots of a DataFrame. 

3040 matplotlib.pyplot.bar : Make a bar plot with matplotlib. 

3041 

3042 Examples 

3043 -------- 

3044 Basic plot. 

3045 

3046 .. plot:: 

3047 :context: close-figs 

3048 

3049 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'lab':['A', 'B', 'C'], 'val':[10, 30, 20]}) 

3050 >>> ax = df.plot.bar(x='lab', y='val', rot=0) 

3051 

3052 Plot a whole dataframe to a bar plot. Each column is assigned a 

3053 distinct color, and each row is nested in a group along the 

3054 horizontal axis. 

3055 

3056 .. plot:: 

3057 :context: close-figs 

3058 

3059 >>> speed = [0.1, 17.5, 40, 48, 52, 69, 88] 

3060 >>> lifespan = [2, 8, 70, 1.5, 25, 12, 28] 

3061 >>> index = ['snail', 'pig', 'elephant', 

3062 ... 'rabbit', 'giraffe', 'coyote', 'horse'] 

3063 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'speed': speed, 

3064 ... 'lifespan': lifespan}, index=index) 

3065 >>> ax = df.plot.bar(rot=0) 

3066 

3067 Instead of nesting, the figure can be split by column with 

3068 ``subplots=True``. In this case, a :class:`numpy.ndarray` of 

3069 :class:`matplotlib.axes.Axes` are returned. 

3070 

3071 .. plot:: 

3072 :context: close-figs 

3073 

3074 >>> axes = df.plot.bar(rot=0, subplots=True) 

3075 >>> axes[1].legend(loc=2) # doctest: +SKIP 

3076 

3077 Plot a single column. 

3078 

3079 .. plot:: 

3080 :context: close-figs 

3081 

3082 >>> ax = df.plot.bar(y='speed', rot=0) 

3083 

3084 Plot only selected categories for the DataFrame. 

3085 

3086 .. plot:: 

3087 :context: close-figs 

3088 

3089 >>> ax = df.plot.bar(x='lifespan', rot=0) 

3090 """ 

3091 return self(kind='bar', x=x, y=y, **kwds)

3093 def barh(self, x=None, y=None, **kwds): 

3094 """ 

3095 Make a horizontal bar plot. 

3096 

3097 A horizontal bar plot is a plot that presents quantitative data with 

3098 rectangular bars with lengths proportional to the values that they

3100 axis of the plot shows the specific categories being compared, and the 

3101 other axis represents a measured value. 

3102 

3103 Parameters

3107 y : label or position, default All numeric columns in dataframe

3119 pandas.DataFrame.plot : Make plots of DataFrame using matplotlib.

3140 ... 'rabbit', 'giraffe', 'coyote', 'horse'] 

3141 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'speed': speed, 

3142 ... 'lifespan': lifespan}, index=index)

3167 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'speed': speed, 

3168 ... 'lifespan': lifespan}, index=index) 

3169 >>> ax = df.plot.barh(x='lifespan') 

3170 """ 

3171 return self(kind='barh', x=x, y=y, **kwds)

3173 def box(self, by=None, **kwds): 

3174 r""" 

3175 Make a box plot of the DataFrame columns. 

3176 

3177 A box plot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical 

3178 data through their quartiles. 

3179 The box extends from the Q1 to Q3 quartile values of the data, 

3180 with a line at the median (Q2). The whiskers extend from the edges 

3181 of box to show the range of the data. The position of the whiskers 

3182 is set by default to 1.5*IQR (IQR = Q3 - Q1) from the edges of the 

3183 box. Outlier points are those past the end of the whiskers. 

3184 

3185 For further details see Wikipedia's 

3186 entry for `boxplot <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Box_plot>`__. 

3187 

3188 A consideration when using this chart is that the box and the whiskers 

3189 can overlap, which is very common when plotting small sets of data. 

3190 

3191 Parameters 

3192 ---------- 

3193 by : string or sequence 

3194 Column in the DataFrame to group by. 

3195 **kwds : optional 

3196 Additional keywords are documented in 

3197 :meth:`pandas.DataFrame.plot`. 

3198 

3199 Returns 

3200 ------- 

3201 axes : :class:`matplotlib.axes.Axes` or numpy.ndarray of them 

3202 

3203 See Also 

3204 -------- 

3205 pandas.DataFrame.boxplot: Another method to draw a box plot. 

3206 pandas.Series.plot.box: Draw a box plot from a Series object. 

3207 matplotlib.pyplot.boxplot: Draw a box plot in matplotlib. 

3208 

3209 Examples 

3210 -------- 

3211 Draw a box plot from a DataFrame with four columns of randomly 

3212 generated data. 

3213 

3214 .. plot:: 

3215 :context: close-figs 

3216 

3217 >>> data = np.random.randn(25, 4) 

3218 >>> df = pd.DataFrame(data, columns=list('ABCD')) 

3219 >>> ax = df.plot.box() 

3220 """ 

3221 return self(kind='box', by=by, **kwds)

3223 def hist(self, by=None, bins=10, **kwds): 

3224 """ 

3225 Draw one histogram of the DataFrame's columns. 

3226 

3227 A histogram is a representation of the distribution of data. 

3228 This function groups the values of all given Series in the DataFrame 

3229 into bins and draws all bins in one :class:`matplotlib.axes.Axes`. 

3230 This is useful when the DataFrame's Series are in a similar scale. 

3231 

3232 Parameters 

3233 ---------- 

3234 by : str or sequence, optional 

3235 Column in the DataFrame to group by. 

3236 bins : int, default 10 

3237 Number of histogram bins to be used. 

3238 **kwds 

3239 Additional keyword arguments are documented in 

3240 :meth:`pandas.DataFrame.plot`. 

3241 

3242 Returns 

3243 ------- 

3244 axes : matplotlib.AxesSubplot histogram. 

3245 

3246 See Also 

3247 -------- 

3248 DataFrame.hist : Draw histograms per DataFrame's Series. 

3249 Series.hist : Draw a histogram with Series' data. 

3250 

3251 Examples 

3252 -------- 

3253 When we draw a dice 6000 times, we expect to get each value around 1000 

3254 times. But when we draw two dices and sum the result, the distribution 

3255 is going to be quite different. A histogram illustrates those 

3256 distributions. 

3257 

3258 .. plot:: 

3259 :context: close-figs 

3260 

3261 >>> df = pd.DataFrame( 

3262 ... np.random.randint(1, 7, 6000), 

3263 ... columns = ['one']) 

3264 >>> df['two'] = df['one'] + np.random.randint(1, 7, 6000) 

3265 >>> ax = df.plot.hist(bins=12, alpha=0.5) 

3266 """ 

3267 return self(kind='hist', by=by, bins=bins, **kwds)

3273 Given several Series of points randomly sampled from unknown

3282 ... 'x': [1, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 5], 

3283 ... 'y': [4, 4, 4.5, 5, 5.5, 6, 6], 

3284 ... }) 

3285 >>> ax = df.plot.kde() 

3286 

3287 A scalar bandwidth can be specified. Using a small bandwidth value can 

3288 lead to over-fitting, while using a large bandwidth value may result 

3289 in under-fitting: 

3290

3296 .. plot::

3300

3302 plot of the estimated PDF: 

3303 

3304 .. plot:: 

3305 :context: close-figs 

3306 

3307 >>> ax = df.plot.kde(ind=[1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6]) 

3308 """.strip() 

3309 })

3437 def scatter(self, x, y, s=None, c=None, **kwds): 

3438 """ 

3439 Create a scatter plot with varying marker point size and color. 

3440 

3441 The coordinates of each point are defined by two dataframe columns and 

3442 filled circles are used to represent each point. This kind of plot is 

3443 useful to see complex correlations between two variables. Points could 

3444 be for instance natural 2D coordinates like longitude and latitude in 

3445 a map or, in general, any pair of metrics that can be plotted against 

3446 each other. 

3447 

3448 Parameters 

3449 ---------- 

3450 x : int or str 

3451 The column name or column position to be used as horizontal 

3452 coordinates for each point. 

3453 y : int or str 

3454 The column name or column position to be used as vertical 

3455 coordinates for each point. 

3456 s : scalar or array_like, optional 

3457 The size of each point. Possible values are: 

3458 

3459 - A single scalar so all points have the same size. 

3460 

3461 - A sequence of scalars, which will be used for each point's size 

3462 recursively. For instance, when passing [2,14] all points size 

3463 will be either 2 or 14, alternatively. 

3464 

3465 c : str, int or array_like, optional 

3466 The color of each point. Possible values are: 

3467 

3468 - A single color string referred to by name, RGB or RGBA code, 

3469 for instance 'red' or '#a98d19'. 

3470 

3471 - A sequence of color strings referred to by name, RGB or RGBA 

3472 code, which will be used for each point's color recursively. For 

3473 instance ['green','yellow'] all points will be filled in green or 

3474 yellow, alternatively. 

3475 

3476 - A column name or position whose values will be used to color the 

3477 marker points according to a colormap. 

3478 

3479 **kwds 

3480 Keyword arguments to pass on to :meth:`pandas.DataFrame.plot`. 

3481 

3482 Returns 

3483 ------- 

3484 axes : :class:`matplotlib.axes.Axes` or numpy.ndarray of them 

3485 

3486 See Also 

3487 -------- 

3488 matplotlib.pyplot.scatter : Scatter plot using multiple input data 

3489 formats. 

3490 

3491 Examples 

3492 -------- 

3493 Let's see how to draw a scatter plot using coordinates from the values 

3494 in a DataFrame's columns. 

3495 

3496 .. plot:: 

3497 :context: close-figs 

3498 

3499 >>> df = pd.DataFrame([[5.1, 3.5, 0], [4.9, 3.0, 0], [7.0, 3.2, 1], 

3500 ... [6.4, 3.2, 1], [5.9, 3.0, 2]], 

3501 ... columns=['length', 'width', 'species']) 

3502 >>> ax1 = df.plot.scatter(x='length', 

3503 ... y='width', 

3504 ... c='DarkBlue') 

3505 

3506 And now with the color determined by a column as well. 

3507 

3508 .. plot:: 

3509 :context: close-figs 

3510 

3511 >>> ax2 = df.plot.scatter(x='length', 

3512 ... y='width', 

3513 ... c='species', 

3514 ... colormap='viridis') 

3515 """ 

3516 return self(kind='scatter', x=x, y=y, c=c, s=s, **kwds)

3518 def hexbin(self, x, y, C=None, reduce_C_function=None, gridsize=None, 

3519 **kwds): 

3520 """ 

3521 Generate a hexagonal binning plot. 

3522 

3523 Generate a hexagonal binning plot of `x` versus `y`. If `C` is `None` 

3524 (the default), this is a histogram of the number of occurrences 

3525 of the observations at ``(x[i], y[i])``. 

3526 

3527 If `C` is specified, specifies values at given coordinates 

3528 ``(x[i], y[i])``. These values are accumulated for each hexagonal 

3529 bin and then reduced according to `reduce_C_function`, 

3530 having as default the NumPy's mean function (:meth:`numpy.mean`). 

3531 (If `C` is specified, it must also be a 1-D sequence 

3532 of the same length as `x` and `y`, or a column label.) 

3533 

3534 Parameters 

3535 ---------- 

3536 x : int or str 

3537 The column label or position for x points. 

3538 y : int or str 

3539 The column label or position for y points. 

3540 C : int or str, optional 

3541 The column label or position for the value of `(x, y)` point. 

3542 reduce_C_function : callable, default `np.mean` 

3543 Function of one argument that reduces all the values in a bin to 

3544 a single number (e.g. `np.mean`, `np.max`, `np.sum`, `np.std`). 

3545 gridsize : int or tuple of (int, int), default 100 

3546 The number of hexagons in the x-direction. 

3547 The corresponding number of hexagons in the y-direction is 

3548 chosen in a way that the hexagons are approximately regular. 

3549 Alternatively, gridsize can be a tuple with two elements 

3550 specifying the number of hexagons in the x-direction and the 

3551 y-direction. 

3552 **kwds 

3553 Additional keyword arguments are documented in 

3554 :meth:`pandas.DataFrame.plot`. 

3555 

3556 Returns 

3557 ------- 

3558 matplotlib.AxesSubplot 

3559 The matplotlib ``Axes`` on which the hexbin is plotted. 

3560 

3561 See Also 

3562 -------- 

3563 DataFrame.plot : Make plots of a DataFrame. 

3564 matplotlib.pyplot.hexbin : Hexagonal binning plot using matplotlib, 

3565 the matplotlib function that is used under the hood. 

3566 

3567 Examples 

3568 -------- 

3569 The following examples are generated with random data from 

3570 a normal distribution. 

3571 

3572 .. plot:: 

3573 :context: close-figs 

3574 

3575 >>> n = 10000 

3576 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({'x': np.random.randn(n), 

3577 ... 'y': np.random.randn(n)}) 

3578 >>> ax = df.plot.hexbin(x='x', y='y', gridsize=20) 

3579 

3580 The next example uses `C` and `np.sum` as `reduce_C_function`. 

3581 Note that `'observations'` values ranges from 1 to 5 but the result 

3582 plot shows values up to more than 25. This is because of the 

3583 `reduce_C_function`. 

3584 

3585 .. plot:: 

3586 :context: close-figs 

3587 

3588 >>> n = 500 

3589 >>> df = pd.DataFrame({ 

3590 ... 'coord_x': np.random.uniform(-3, 3, size=n), 

3591 ... 'coord_y': np.random.uniform(30, 50, size=n), 

3592 ... 'observations': np.random.randint(1,5, size=n) 

3593 ... }) 

3594 >>> ax = df.plot.hexbin(x='coord_x', 

3595 ... y='coord_y', 

3596 ... C='observations', 

3597 ... reduce_C_function=np.sum, 

3598 ... gridsize=10, 

3599 ... cmap="viridis") 

3600 """ 

3601 if reduce_C_function is not None: 

3602 kwds['reduce_C_function'] = reduce_C_function 

3603 if gridsize is not None: 

3604 kwds['gridsize'] = gridsize 

3605 return self(kind='hexbin', x=x, y=y, C=C, **kwds)
